column2: Verb. To make formal changes to a document or contract. Example: The agreement was amended before signing.
Noun. The existing state of affairs. Example: They have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.
Verb. To quickly remove something or someone. Example: The baby was plucked from a grim foster home.
Adjective. Worn and shabby, in poor condition. Example: Many public places are tatty at best.
Adjective. Very poor or bad. Example: The service is usually lousy.
Adjective. Feeling bored or lacking enthusiasm after too much of something. Example: You soon become jaded with flying.
Noun. A person falsely claiming special knowledge or skill. Example: The healer was a charlatan selling fake remedies.
Noun/Verb. The act of guiding or directing movement. Example: Effective steering is essential for safe driving.
Verb. To make a sudden movement to the side. Example: The driver had to swerve to avoid the deer.
Noun. Favoring one’s own products or services over others. Example: The ruling addressed the company’s self-preferencing practices.
Verb. Violating a law or agreement. Example: Breaching the contract will result in a fine.
Noun/Adjective. An important or historic decision or event. Example: The court issued a landmark ruling.
Verb. Controls access or limits participation. Example: The editor gatekeeps which articles get published.
Adjective. Fearless and adventurous. Example: The intrepid explorer crossed the desert alone.
Adjective + Noun. People exhausted from travel. Example: The weary travellers rested by the roadside.
Adjective. Showing good judgment and care. Example: His judicious use of resources saved money.
Adjective. Able to notice or appreciate fine details. Example: She has a discerning eye for quality art.
Adjective (contextual). Long-established and unlikely to change. Example: The organisation’s rules are invertebrate.
Noun. People who aggressively persuade travellers to choose certain hotels. Example: Be wary of hotel touts.
Adjective + Noun. Bad or inappropriate accommodation. Example: We stayed in unsuitable lodgings.
Adverbial phrase. Without success. Example: They searched for the keys in vain.
Noun. A state of perfect happiness or joy. Example: Listening to the waves felt like pure bliss.
Noun. A state of disbelief. Example: She reacted with incredulity.
Noun. Lack of interest or concern. Example: His apathy toward school worried teachers.
Noun. A feeling of sadness caused by disappointment. Example: The team sat in silent rejection.
Noun. Deep sadness due to loss or misfortune. Example: She felt sorrow when her friend moved away.
Noun. Great joy or pleasure. Example: The children shouted with delight.
Noun. A strong feeling of disgust. Example: He turned away in revulsion.
Noun. Intense anger. Example: She shouted in fury.
Noun. Intense hatred or disgust. Example: He felt loathing for the corrupt politician.
Noun. The state of being boring or monotonous. Example: He couldn’t stand the tedium of waiting.
Noun/Verb. Strong fear or anxiety about something. Example: She felt dread before the exam.
Verb. Mocked using humor or exaggeration. Example: His mistakes were satirized on TV.
Noun. Display of traits stereotypically considered feminine. Example: Critics commented on the effeminacy of his gestures.
Verb. To spread or increase rapidly. Example: Rumors proliferate on social media.
Adjective phrase. Popular or fashionable. Example: That trend is currently in vogue.
Adjective. Having a substantial amount of flesh. Example: The mango was ripe and fleshy.
Adjective. Sweet, rich, and pleasant in taste. Example: The cake was topped with luscious berries.
Adjective. Giving deep sensory pleasure. Example: Eating the pear was a sensuous experience.
Verb. To exist in large quantities. Example: Rumors of scandal abound.
Verb. To happen as a result of something. Example: A series of changes ensued.
Adjective. Too ripe and beginning to decay. Example: The overripe bananas were used for bread.
Verb. To consider or judge. Example: The area was deemed safe.
Verb. To place in a lower position or rank. Example: She was relegated to a desk job.
Noun. The expected future situation. Example: The outlook for today is cloudy.
Noun. A state of hopeless unhappiness. Example: A mood of despondency set in.
Adjective. Detailed and careful. Example: A thorough revision was required.
Adjective. Out of place or inappropriate. Example: The computer looked incongruous in the library.
Adjective. Tall, thin, and awkward in movement. Example: A tall, gangly boy entered the room.
Verb. To make small restless movements. Example: He fidgeted with a pencil.
Adjective. Slow and lacking energy. Example: She spoke in a languid voice.
Adjective. Strongly biased or supportive without objectivity. Example: The audience was highly partisan.
Verb. To walk unsteadily. Example: He staggered to the phone.
Verb. To push roughly in a crowd. Example: Fans jostled for space.
Phrasal verb. To repair, paint, or improve something old. Example: I need to do up my old bicycle before selling it.
Phrasal verb. To use all of a supply of something. Example: We used up all the flour baking cakes.
Phrasal verb. To originate from or be caused by something. Example: Her health problems stem from a sedentary lifestyle.
Phrasal verb. To offer an idea or suggestion for consideration. Example: He put forward several points during the discussion.
Phrasal verb. To use experience, skills, or knowledge as a resource. Example: Drawing on my experience, I believe this will work.
Phrasal verb. To explain or be the reason for something, or to form part of a total. Example: Poverty accounts for the rise in crime.
Phrasal verb. To attribute something to a particular cause. Example: We put the children’s behaviour down to excitement.
Phrasal verb. To make a tentative or provisional arrangement. Example: Let’s pencil in the meeting for next Tuesday.
Idiom. To refuse to change your opinion despite criticism. Example: Despite the criticism, she stuck to her guns.
Idiom. To start behaving better or change your life positively. Example: He decided to turn over a new leaf and go back to college.
Idiom/Phrasal verb. To pay a large amount of money, often unwillingly. Example: I had to fork out nearly a thousand dollars.
Idiom/Adjective. Completely determined about something. Example: She is dead set on moving to Paris.
Idiom/Phrase. To push people out of your way, especially in a crowd. Example: He elbowed people aside to reach the front.
Idiom. To accept unpleasant consequences. Example: He had to face the music after skipping class.
Idiom. To pay for something expensive or unexpected. Example: He agreed to foot the bill for dinner.
Idiom. To take on a difficult responsibility. Example: She shouldered the burden of caring for her parents.
Idiom. To tolerate or accept an unpleasant thought. Example: I can’t stomach the idea of working weekends.
Idiom. To conform to rules or expectations. Example: Employees must toe the line.
Noun/Verb. The characteristic sound made by a horse. Example: A loud neigh came from the stable.
Idiom. Something that makes a good situation even better. Example: The company car was the icing on the cake.
Idiom. To have more important things to do. Example: I have bigger fish to fry right now.
Idiom. To make something unpleasant easier to accept. Example: A bonus was offered to sweeten the pill.
Idiom. To reveal a secret. Example: John spilled the beans about the surprise party.
Idiom. To be embarrassed after being proven wrong. Example: The politician got egg on his face.
Idiom. To admit you were wrong and apologise. Example: I had to eat humble pie after criticising her idea.
Idiom. Mutual compromise by both sides. Example: A good relationship needs give and take.
Idiom/Adverbial. Repeatedly or frequently. Example: She has proven it time and again.
Idiom. Abandoned without help or support. Example: The workers were left high and dry.
Idiom/Noun phrase. Success, wealth, and recognition. Example: He went to Hollywood seeking fame and fortune.
Idiom/Adverbial. Most importantly. Example: First and foremost, we must consider safety.
Idiom/Adjective. Very clear with no ambiguity. Example: The rules are written in black and white.
Idiom/Adverbial. Through good and bad times. Example: They stayed together through thick and thin.
Idiom/Adjective. Very uncertain or risky. Example: The operation was touch and go.
Idiom/Noun phrase. A real human being with limitations, or a relative. Example: I’m only flesh and blood.

column1: Life and soul of the party
column2: Idiom/Noun phrase. The most lively and entertaining person. Example: She’s the life and soul of the party.
Phrase. The correct orientation or position. Example: Make sure the battery is the right way round.
Idiom/Phrase. To be a deserved punishment. Example: It served him right for cheating.
Idiom/Phrase. In an obvious place that went unnoticed. Example: The keys were right under your nose.
Idiom/Phrase. To say what people expect, often without sincerity. Example: He made all the right noises during the campaign.
Phrase. Legally or morally entitled to do something. Example: You are within your rights to complain.
Phrase/Adverbial. According to what is fair or deserved. Example: By rights, she should have been promoted.
Idiom/Phrase. Morally or factually correct. Example: She proved she was in the right.
Idiom. Perfectly well or healthy again. Example: After resting, I felt as right as rain.
Phrase/Adverbial. Exactly at the expected time. Example: The train arrived right on time.
Noun phrase. Legal permission to adapt a story into a film. Example: The film rights were sold immediately.
Idiom. A way to wish someone good luck. Example: They told her to break a leg before the show.

column1: Cost an arm and a leg
column2: Idiom. To be very expensive. Example: That car costs an arm and a leg.
Idiom. Ready and eager to listen. Example: Tell me everything, I’m all ears.
Idiom. To annoy or irritate someone. Example: The noise is getting on my nerves.
Idiom. To hope for good luck. Example: Keep your fingers crossed for my interview.
Idiom. To agree with someone. Example: We don’t always see eye to eye.

column1: Be left to your own devices
column2: Idiom. To be free to act independently. Example: She was left to her own devices.
Idiom. To do something in a new or unconventional way. Example: She enjoys breaking the mould.
Verb. To represent or show something in a picture or a story. Example: Her paintings depict the lives of ordinary people in the last century.
Verb. To assing as a share or a portion. Example: Allot 10 minutes for the speech.
Verb. To move in a confused or disordered manner. The contest editor has jumbled the letters of some common words
Idiom. To keep up with or maintain informed. I need to stay abreast of the latest changes in the law.
Verb. To fly or move quickly and lightly. Example: In the fading light, we saw bats flitting about in the garden.
Noun. An official announcement. Example: A bloody civil war followed the proclamation of an independent state.
Noun. The character of a place or the quality it seems to have. Example: Despite being a busy city, Dublin has the ambience of a country town.
Verb. To make someone feel fresher, healthier and more energetic. Example: We were invigorated by our walk.
Phrasal verb. To control something and stop it increasing. Consumers tend to rein in their spending in a recession.
Noun. A long piece of material,especially leather, that helps you to control and direct a horse. Example: You pull both reins to stop or slow a horse, but only the left rain to turn left.
Noun. A time when all the people involved in a play, dance, etc, practise, in order to prepare for a performance. Example: He's a producer with three plays in rehearsal.
Verb. To avoid doing or stop yourself from doing something. Example: We refrained from talking until we knew it was safe.
Adjectvie. To be unwilling to do something. Example: I'm loath to spent it all at once.
Verb. To become less strong. Example: A healthy diet lessen the risk of a heart disease.
Idiom. Past the time when something should have happened. Example: It’s high time you got that bad knee looked at by a doctor!
Adjective. Made or done in a careful or decorative way. Example: The new album contains some carefully wrought new songs and a number of familiar hits.
Adjective. Brave in a silly way, taking uncessary risks. Example: a foolhardy decision.
Noun. A feeling of great respect sometimes mixed with a fear or surprise. Example: I've always held musicans in awe.
Noun. Strong and unhappiness, especially about personal problems. Example: All my children went through a period of late-adolesecent angst.
Adjective. Intelligent with words in a fun way. Example: He was witty and very charming.
Noun. The hability to say or do the same thing without making anyone unhappy or angry. Example: He's never had much tact and people don't like his blunt manner.
Adjective. Do something suddently without considering the results of your actions. Example: He's so impetuous, why can't he think things over before he rushes into them?
Adjective. Showing little enthusiasm and effort. Example: The food was nice enough but the service was somewhat lackdaisical.
Adjective. Rude and unfriendly. She has a rather abrasive manner.
Adjective. Thinking that you are more imporant or more intelligent that you really are. Example: She's so bigheaded!
Adjective. Too productive and considering yourselfto be very imporant. Example: She's so stuck up, she won't even talk to us.
Adjective. Unreasonably determined, especially to act in a particular way and not to change at all, despite waht anyone else says. Example: He can be very obstinate at times.
Adjective. Someone who is loquacious talks a lot. Example: I was talking, as one always does, to a luquaciois taxi driver.
Idiom. To become very angry. Example: People who don't finish a job really make me see red.
Phrasal verb. Discussing what changes need to be made to change something. Example: Certain improvements ought to be carry out for economic purposes.
Phrasal verb. To state an idea or opinion, or suggest a plan or a person. Example: This email was put forwards to address.
Phrasal verb. To start or develop as the result of something. Example: Her problems stem from her difficult childhood.
Verb. To explain something or make something clear. Example: I don't understand. You'll have to elucidate.
Verb. To add proof to an account, statement, idea, etc, with new information. Example: Recent research seems to corrobate his thoery.
Verb. To cause something to continue. Example: Incrasig the supply of weapongs will only perpetuate the violence and anarchy.
Verb. To show something to be true, or to support a claim with facts. Example: We've evidence to substantiate the allegations against him.
Verb. To publicly support or suggest an idea, development, or way of doing something. Example: She advocates taking a more long-term view.
Verb. To make someone less confident, less powerful, or less likely to succeed, or to make something waker. Example: Critisicm just undermines their confidence.
Verb. To make a bad or unpleasant situation better. Example: foreign aid is badly needed to ameliorate the effects of the drought.

Verb. To critizice someone or something in a way that shows you don't respect or value him, her, or it. Example: The actor's work for charity has recently been disparaged in the press as an attempo to get publicity.
Verb. To make something possible or easier. The new rampo will facilitate the entry of wheelchairs.
